title: Worship & Services - Frequently Asked Questions
subtitle: What to Expect During Orthodox Tewahdo Worship
author: Liturgical Committee
excerpt: Practical guidance for participating in Orthodox Tewahdo worship services, including liturgy, fasting, and feast day observances.

sections.title: What should I expect during the Divine Liturgy?
content: The **Divine Liturgy (Kidase)** is the central worship service of our church, typically lasting 2-3 hours. Here's what to expect:
**Language**: The liturgy is celebrated in **Ge'ez**, the ancient liturgical language, with some explanations in English and Tigrinya.
**Standing Worship**: Traditional Orthodox worship involves **standing for most of the service**, though seating is available for those who need it.
**Participation**: Congregation joins in **responses, hymns, and prayers**. Don't worry if you're unfamiliar - you'll learn gradually.
**Communion**: Only **baptized Orthodox Christians** who have prepared through fasting and confession may receive communion.
**Dress Code**: **Modest, respectful attire** is expected. Women traditionally cover their heads during worship.
**For detailed liturgy guide**, see our comprehensive article: [Understanding the Divine Liturgy (Kidase)](#articles) in our Articles section.

sections.title: When and where are services held?
content: **Regular Sunday Services:**
- **Divine Liturgy**: Sundays at 9:00 AM
- **Sunday School**: After liturgy, 1:00 PM - 2:30 PM
**Location**: [Church address and directions available on our Contact page](#contact)
**Special Services:**
- **Feast Day Celebrations**: Times vary by occasion
- **Lenten Services**: Additional services during fasting periods
- **Wedding and Baptism**: By appointment with clergy
**Holiday Schedule**: Services may have different times during major Orthodox holidays. Check our announcements or contact the church office for current schedules.

sections.title: Are there special feast days I should know about?
content: The Orthodox Church celebrates numerous **feast days** throughout the year. Major celebrations include:
**Major Feasts:**
- **Genna (Christmas)**: January 7th - Birth of Christ
- **Timkat (Epiphany)**: January 19th - Baptism of Christ
- **Fasika (Easter)**: Date varies - Resurrection of Christ
- **Meskel**: September 27th - Finding of the True Cross
**Marian Feasts:**
- **Assumption of Mary**: August 15th
- **Nativity of Mary**: September 1st
**Saints' Days**: Including our patron **Saint Michael** and other Orthodox saints
**Feast day services** often include special liturgies, processions, and community celebrations. These are wonderful opportunities to experience the richness of Orthodox tradition.

sections.title: What are fasting rules and why do we observe them?
content: **Fasting is a spiritual discipline** that helps us grow closer to God through self-control, prayer, and compassion for others.
**Major Fasting Periods:**
- **Lent (Hudadi/Abiy Tsom)**: 55 days before Easter
- **Advent Fast**: 40 days before Christmas
- **Fast of the Apostles**: From Monday after Pentecost until June 29th
- **Fast of the Assumption**: August 1-15
**Fasting Guidelines:**
- **Abstain from**: Animal products (meat, dairy, eggs), fish (except certain days)
- **Spiritual focus**: Increased prayer, almsgiving, and spiritual reading
- **Individual circumstances**: Health conditions, pregnancy, age may modify requirements
**For complete fasting guide**, see our detailed article: [Orthodox Fasting: Spiritual Discipline and Growth](#articles) with practical guidance and spiritual insights.
